Enhancing anchoring and catalytic conversion of polysulfides by nitrogen deficient cobalt nitride for advanced lithium-sulfur batteries Min Luo a b Yu Bai a b ⁎ Rui Sun a b Meixiu Qu a b Mengyuan Wang a b Zhanfeng Yang a b Zhenhua Wang b Wang Sun b Kening Sun b a Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Advanced Research Institute of Multidisciplinary Science, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China b Beijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Beijing Key Laboratory for Chemical Power Source and Green Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The CNT-CoN-VN modified separator can promote the anchoring and conversion kinetics of polysulfides as well as the diffusion of Li ions, leading to enhanced electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. While lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery has attracted remarkable attention owing to the high theoretical capacity, its practical application is still hindered by the shuttle and sluggish conversion kinetics of intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). Defect engineering, which can regulate the electronic structure and in turn influence the surface adsorption and catalytic capability, has been regarded as a feasible strategy to deal with the above challenges. However, few studies on nitrogen vacancies and their mechanisms are reported. Herein, cobalt nitride with nitrogen vacancies grown on multi-walled carbon nanotube (CNT-CoN-VN) is designed and applied as the separator modification material to investigate the enhancing mechanism of nitrogen vacancies on Li-S batteries. The experimental evidence and theoretical calculation indicate that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies into cobalt nitride can enhance the chemical affinity to LiPSs and effectively hamper the shuttle effect. Meanwhile the reduced band gap of the d-band center of Co and p-band center of N for CNT-CoN-VN and the promoted diffusion of Li+ can expedite the solid–liquid and liquid–liquid conversions of sulfur species. Due to these superiorities, the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator delivers a favorable initial capacity of 901 mAh g−1 and a capacity of 660 mAh g−1 can be achieved after 250 cycles at 2 C. This work explores the application of metal nitride with nitrogen vacancies and sheds light on the development of functional separators for high-efficient Li-S batteries. Keywords Cobalt nitride Nitrogen vacancy Redox kinetics Separators Li-S batteries 1 Introduction Li-S batteries have attracted considerable attention in view of the need for large-scale electricity storage and electric vehicles, due to their high theoretical specific capacity, abundant reserve and nontoxicity of sulphur [1–3]. However, the practical application of Li-S batteries is still hampered by some obstacles, involving the poor electronic conductivity of sulfur, the shuttle effect of the soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and the large volume expansion in the cyclic process [2,4]. Over the past decades, tremendous efforts have been dedicated into the field of electrode engineering [5], separator modification [6], and electrolyte optimization [7] to address the aforementioned issues. The introduction of a functional layer on separators has drawn great attention in recent years. It has been demonstrated that the separators modified with functional layers can not only mitigate the shuttle effect but also recycle the sulfur species to optimize the electrochemical performance of the Li-S batteries [8,9] while porous carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes [10], grapheme [11], carbon nanospheres [12] have been widely used due to their excellent conductivity and adjustable porosity, the weak van der Waals force between nonpolar carbonaceous materials and polar LiPSs is insufficient to anchor polysulfides and hinder their shuttle effectively [13]. Catalytic performance plays an important role in Li-S battery [14], in this context, a large number of transition metal materials (including metal oxides [15], metal sulphides [16], metal nitrides [17]), semi-immobilized redox mediators [18] and mixed organodiselenides [19] have been utilized to chemically adsorb LiPSs and facilitate their redox conversion. Metal nitrides with high electronic conductivity are recognized as promising materials for Li-S batteries owing to their easily adjustable electronic structure and high catalytic activity [20–22]. Huang et al. prepared the Co4N-based pre-catalysts for Li-S batteries and revealed that the electrochemical phase evolution of Co4N into CoS x during the electrochemical cycling process could enhance the activity of the catalyst [20]. Zhang et al. reported the modification of separator by InN nanowires, which was demonstrated to be efficient in immobilization and catalytic transformation for LiPSs [22]. Therefore, it is a sensible strategy to combine the highly conductive carbon materials with the transition metal nitrides which can enhance the adsorption of LiPSs through chemical interaction and facilitate the redox conversion of LiPSs by accelerating the electron transfer process [23,24]. Surface defects engineering, which can adjust the electronic structure of materials, plays an important role in promoting electrical conductivity and charge transfer kinetics [25]. Recently, cationic, and anionic vacancy engineering has aroused wide public concern in expediting the chemical anchor and the sulfur redox chemistry in Li-S batteries [26–32]. However the study on N vacancies in Li-S chemistry, especially the mechanism in the catalytic conversion of lithium polysulfides hasn’t been deeply investigated. In this paper, CoN with good catalytic activity and electrical conductivity is used to study the effect of N vacancies in Li-S Chemistry. And the enhancing mechanisms of nitrogen vacancies on the adsorption and conversion of lithium polysulfides are studied. Cobalt nitride with nitrogen vacancies grown on multi-walled carbon nanotube (CNT-CoN-VN) is designed and applied as the separator modification material. Through constructing nitrogen vacancies defects, the electronic structure of CoN is optimized and the derived CNT-CoN-VN delivers favorable chemical affinity to LiPSs as well as electrochemical reaction kinetics, thus effectively inhibiting the shuttle of LiPSs and improving the utilization of active species. The theoretical calculation further clarifies the reduced band gap of d-band center of Co and p-band center of N in CNT-CoN-VN and the low diffusion energy barriers for LiPSs on the surface of CNT-CoN-VN. Due to the superiority of the above nitrogen vacancies, the cell with the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator delivers favorable cycling performance and obtain a capacity of 660 mAh g−1 after 250 cycles at 2 C. This work opens new doors of opportunity towards developing advanced functional interlayers for Li-S batteries via nitrogen vacancies engineering. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN To prepare CNT-CoN powders, 142 mg of cobalt acetate tetrahydrate were completely dissolved in enough ethanol, then added 157 mg CNT and the above solution was stirred evenly for 15 min, then 1.8 mL deionized water and 1 mL ammonia were added and the sealed solution was stirred at 80 °C. The CNT-Co3O4 powders were acquired by centrifugation, washing and freeze-drying. The as prepared CNT-Co3O4 was converted into CNT-CoN under NH3 flow at 300 °C. The CNT-CoN-VN powders were obtained by calcining CNT-CoN powders at 350 °C in Ar/H2 atmosphere. 2.2 Preparation of the CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators The CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN slurries were made by blending the Super P and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methylpyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent. The mass mixing ratio of CNT/CNT-CoN/CNT-CoN-VN: Super P: PVDF was set to 6:3:1. The modified separators were prepared by coating the CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN slurries on the cathode side of the separators (Celgard 2325) and vacuum dried at 50 °C for 12 h. The loadings of the separators modification layer were ∼0.5 mg cm−2. 2.3 Materials characterization Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Regulus 8230, Hitachi, Japan) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F, Tokyo, Japan) were used to research the morphology and microstructure of synthesized materials. The crystal structures were studied using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu K α radiation). Kratos Axis Ultra was employed to operate X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The proportion of CoN in CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN was measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, 449 F5 Jupiter). The obtained N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms by the Autosorb-IQ2-MP-C instrument to determine the porous structure. Bruker EMXPLUS was used to record Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) signals. UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-3600, Japan) was utilized to test the UV–vis absorption spectra. 2.4 Adsorption tests S and Li2S powders were blended with a molar ratio of 5:1 in 1, 3-dioxolane (DOL)/1, 2-dimethoxyethane (DME) (v:v, 1:1) to prepare Li2S6 solution, along with violent stir. The solution concentration was determined to be 25 mmol L−1 (in sulfur). The Li2S6 solution (2 mM) for visualized adsorption tests was prepared by diluting the concentrated solution with DOL/DME (v:v, 1:1). 10 mg of CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN powders were placed in vials, respectively. Finally, the mixed solutions were shaken gently and then left to stand for 12 h before being photographed. 2.5 H-type cell tests The H-type cell test was conducted in a glovebox filled with argon. The left chamber and the right chamber of H-type cell were isolated by CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators, respectively. And the separators modification layers face the left chamber of H-type cell. The left chamber holds Li2S6 solution (0.02 M; 6 mL) and right chamber contains the solution of DOL/DME (v:v = 1:1; 6 mL). 2.6 Assembly of Li2S6 symmetric cells and the electrochemical measurements The current collector of symmetric cells was identified as carbon fiber paper (CP). The CP purchased from Toray Company is a thin film substrate with a thickness of ∼0.19 mm and a density of ∼0.44 g cm−3. 0.45 mg cm−2 CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN powders were dispersed onto CP disks with a diameter of 12 mm. The cell consisted of two identical electrodes, Celgard 2325 separator and 40 μL Li2S6 (2.5 mol L−1 in sulfur) electrolyte. Electrochemical workstation (PGSTAT 302 N) was used to test the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). CV was perfomed at a scan rate of 200 mV s−1 from −1.0 to 1.0 V. EIS was conducted with an amplitude of 10 mV between 100 mHz and 100 kHz. 2.7 Transference number of lithium ions The lithium ion transference number for CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators was identified with chronoamperometry at a constant step potential of 10 mV. Each separator was placed between two lithium metal electrodes in a cell (CR2025) and the lithium ion transference number (t Li +) was figured from the ratio of steady state current (I s) to initial state current (I o) on the basis of the following equation. t Li + = I s / I o 2.8 Ionic conductivity The ionic conductivity of CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators was calculated from EIS spectra. Each separator infiltrated in the electrolyte was put between two stainless steel electrodes in a cell, and its ionic conductivity was figured on the basis of the following equation. σ = l / ( R b · A ) where σ represented ionic conductivity, l was the thickness of the separator, R b stood for the bulk resistance, and A referred to the area of the stainless steel electrode. 2.9 Assembly of Li-S batteries and the electrochemical measurements The cathode with the sulfur loading of approximately 2.5 mg cm−2 was fabricated by mixing the sulfur powder, Super P and PVDF (mass ratio 6:3:1) in NMP solvent, then spreading the slurry onto CP evenly and fully drying. The cathodes with increased sulfur loadings (2.5, 3.5 and 4.5 mg cm−2) were also prepared. The cell was assembled with the Celgard 2325, CNT, CNT-CoN or CNT-CoN-VN modified separator placed between the cathode and lithium anode in a glovebox filled with argon. The electrolyte contained 1.0 M lithium bis (trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) and 2% LiNO3 in DOL/DME (v:v, 1:1). Galvanostatic charge/discharge was carried out between 1.6 and 2.8 V with LAND CT2001A instrument (Wuhan JinnuoElectronic Co. Ltd.). The ratio of electrolyte and sulfur was 20 μL mg−1. 2.10 Theoretical calculation The Vienna Ab Initio Package (VASP) [33] was employed to carry out all the density functional theory (DFT) calculations within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the PBE [34] formulation. The projected augmented wave (PAW) potentials [35] were chosen to depict the ionic cores and take valence electrons into account using a plane wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 450 eV. Partial occupancies of the Kohn-Sham orbitals were permitted using the Gaussian smearing method and a width of 0.05 eV. The electronic energy was regarded as self-consistent when the energy change was smaller than 10−4 eV. A geometry optimization was viewed as convergent when the force change was smaller than 0.05 eV Å−1. Grimme’s DFT-D3 methodology [36] was employed to depict the dispersion interactions. During structural optimizations, the 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid for Brillouin zone was utilized as k-point sampling of structures. Finally, the adsorption energies (E ads) were calculated as E ads = E ad/sub − E ad − E sub, where E ad/sub, E ad, and E sub represented the total energies of the optimized adsorbate/substrate system, the adsorbate in the structure, and the clean substrate, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The preparation process of cobalt nitride with nitrogen vacancies grown on multi-walled carbon nanotube (CNT-CoN-VN) is illustrated in Scheme 1 . The Co3O4 was first grown on CNT through a simple oil bath treatment route. Then, the as-prepared CNT-Co3O4 was converted into CNT-CoN by annealing at 300 °C in Ar/NH3 (90%/10%) flow. After that, the derived CNT-CoN was calcined at 350 °C in an Ar/H2 (95%/5%) atmosphere to introduce nitrogen vacancies into the CNT-CoN, then transformed into CNT-CoN-VN through calcining at 350 °C in an Ar/H2 (95%/5%) atmosphere. The morphology and microstructure of the as prepared materials were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). FE-SEM images (Fig. S1b) indicate that numerous nanoparticles with sizes of about 20–40 nm are grown on the surface of CNT compared with CNT (Fig. S1a). After calcining at 350 °C in reducing atmosphere, the morphology of CNT-CoN has no obvious change as shown in Fig. S1(c). HR-TEM images in Fig. 1(a) manifest the fringe spacings of 0.25 and 0.21 nm for CNT-CoN, which is in agreement with the (111) and (200) crystal planes of CNT-CoN. Fig. 1(b) further validates the existence of abundant defects in the CNT-CoN-VN. (Outlined in red dashed in the HR-TEM image) The elemental mapping images in Fig. S2 indicate that the Co, N, C and O elements are uniformly distributed within the CNT-CoN-VN. Besides, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves and X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN after heat treatment in the air are shown in Fig. S3. Obviously, the CoN can be transformed into Co3O4 after heating at 900 °C in the air. According to the TGA results, the proportion of CoN in CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN is calculated to be 21.6 and 21.1 wt%, respectively. It indicates that the introduction of the nitrogen vacancies defects has no significant influence on the loading of CoN on CNT. The XRD pattern of CNT-Co3O4 in Fig. 2(a) shows obvious characteristic diffraction peaks that can be indexed to Co3O4 (JCPDS#43-1003), indicating the successful synthesis of Co3O4. The diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 36.7°, 42.7° and 61.3° for CNT-CoN correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of CoN with cubic structure (JCPDS#16-0116), respectively, verifying that the Co3O4 is successfully converted into CoN after calcinating in NH3 atmosphere. The XRD pattern of CNT-CoN-VN remains similar to that of CNT-CoN, confirming that there is no evident phase transformation after annealing CNT-CoN in a reducing atmosphere. However, the peak intensities of CNT-CoN-VN weaken distinctly as compared with those of CNT-CoN, confirming the formation of abundant defects in CNT-CoN-VN [37]. The values of I D/I G in Raman spectra (Fig. 2b) for CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN show little difference, which confirms that the treatment in Ar/NH3 or Ar/H2 atmosphere has little influence on the CNT structure. The surface chemical compositions of CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN were further investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As displayed in Fig. 2(c), the CNT-CoN shows two characteristic peaks of Co 2p 3/2 located at 780.3 (Co–N) and 781.5 eV (Co–O), as well as the corresponding satellite peak at 787.0 eV. The presence of Co–O bond may result from the exposure of cobalt metal in the air [38]. As compared with CNT-CoN, a negative chemical shift of 0.3 eV is observed in Co 2p 3/2 peaks of CNT-CoN-VN (Fig. 2d), indicating the decreased valence state of Co after hydrogen treatment due to the formation of nitrogen vacancies. For the N 1s spectrum of CNT-CoN (Fig. S5a), three main peaks associated with pyridinic N (398.1 eV), Co–N (398.9 eV) and pyrrolic N (400.0 eV) are observed. A positive chemical shift of 0.2 eV is observed for the N 1s spectrum of CNT-CoN-VN (Fig. S5b) compared with CNT-CoN, further confirming the existence of N vacancies in CNT-CoN-VN. As shown in Fig. S5(c and d), the C 1s XPS spectra of CNT-CoN-VN, which show four characteristic peaks centred at 284.6 (C–C), 285.3 (C–N), 286.5 (C–O), and 290.2 eV (CO), are similar to that of CNT-CoN. This result indicates that Ar/H2 treatment has little impact on the structure of N-doped CNTs. The surface defects of CNT-CoN-VN are further verified by Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) characterization. As shown in Fig. 2(e), the CNT-CoN shows almost no signal, while the distinct response peak of CNT-CoN-VN at a g-value of about 2.002 is observed. This strongly demonstrates the existence of unpaired electrons caused by the absence of partial nitrogen atoms [39]. From the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 2f and Fig. S6), the surface areas of CNT-CoN-VN, CNT-CoN and CNT are calculated to be 153, 103, 183 m2 g−1, respectively. Meanwhile, CNT-CoN-VN, CNT-CoN and CNT are mainly composed of micropores and mesopores (inset), which is conducive to the infiltration of electrolyte and the diffusion of lithium ions. The adsorption abilities of CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN towards LiPSs are exhibited in Fig. 3(a). The weaker absorption peak of Li2S6 and the colorless Li2S6 electrolyte indicate that CNT-CoN-VN exerts stronger chemical adsorption to LiPSs. XPS was adopted to further reveal the interaction between the LiPSs and CNT-CoN or CNT-CoN-VN. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the peak of Co-N/S shifts towards higher binding energy after the adsorption of Li2S6, indicating the charge transfer and chemical interaction between CoN and Li2S6 [40,41]. For the peak of Co-N/S in CNT-CoN-VN (Fig. 3c), a larger shift towards high binding energy occurs, showing that there is a stronger interaction between CNT-CoN-VN and Li2S6 [42]. Moreover, in the N 1s spectra (Fig. S7a and b), the Co-N peak of CNT-CoN-VN-Li2S6 shifts to a higher binding energy compared with that of CNT-CoN-Li2S6. The above results reveal that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies can enhance the chemical interaction between LiPSs and CoN. The diffusion test of soluble polysulfides with various modified separators in the H-cell apparatus has been conducted. As shown in Fig. S8(a and b), the Li2S6 solution can easily diffuse across the CNT-CoN and CNT modified separators, leading the color of the solution in the right chamber of H-type cell to turn yellow quickly. In contrast, the color of the solution in the right chamber of H-type cell hardly changes for the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator after 24 h (Fig. S8c), indicating that the shuttle effect has been alleviated by CNT-CoN-VN. In addition to mitigating the shuttle of LiPSs, the remarkable adsorption properties in Li-S batteries can also benefit the multiphase transformation (Li2S8 ↔ Li2S4 ↔ Li2S). In order to deeply understand the conversion kinetics of liquid–liquid phase (Li2S8 ↔ Li2S4), the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of symmetric cells with Li2S6 electrolytes were conducted. As illustrated in the CV spectra (Fig. 3d), the current response for CNT-CoN-VN is the largest, demonstrating that the redox kinetics of the liquid–liquid phase is significantly enhanced. This conclusion is also in accord with the EIS result. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the minimum charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of the CNT-CoN-VN symmetrical cell confirms that the interfacial redox kinetics of Li2S6 is significantly enhanced by CNT-CoN-VN. To further elucidate the catalytic capability of CNT-CoN-VN on the liquid–solid conversion of LiPSs, Li2S precipitation experiments were carried out on the surface of CP-CNT, CP-CNT-CoN and CP-CNT-CoN-VN. As displayed in Fig. 3(f–h), Li2S precipitation on CP-CNT, CP-CNT-CoN and CP-CNT-CoN-VN contributes to the capacity of 173, 207 and 245 mAh g−1, respectively. Moreover, the current peak for CNT-CoN-VN appears earlier at 1178 s than those for CNT-CoN (1470 s) and CNT (1733 s). Therefore, the transformation from Li2S4 to Li2S is strengthened by CNT-CoN-VN due to the high capacity and early emergence of the current peak for Li2S precipitation. The above results confirm that the existence of nitrogen vacancies can accelerate the redox kinetics for liquid–liquid and liquid–solid phase conversion. The mechanism diagram of the adsorption and catalytic conversion process of LiPSs on CNT-CoN-VN is shown in Fig. 3(i). To focus on the separator modification layer before cycling, the FE-SEM characterization was adopted to study the morphology features of CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators (Fig. S9a–c). Clearly, the surface of the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator is tight with no evident fissure. Fig. S9(e–h) shows that the C, O, Co and N elements are distributed uniformly on the surface of CNT-CoN-VN modified separator, verifying the CNT-CoN-VN is evenly dispersed on the Celgard separator. Besides, Fig. S9(d) reveals that the thickness of the CNT-CoN-VN coating layers is about 10 µm and the corresponding surface loading is about 0.5 mg cm−2. The electrochemical performance of cells based on CNT-CoN-VN modified separator is further evaluated. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the cell with the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator exhibits the superb rate performance and the discharge capacities at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 3 C are 1405, 1258, 1123, 939 and 814 mAh g−1, respectively. Besides, almost no irreversible capacity loss is observed when the current density recovers to 0.2 C, indicating the satisfactory reversibility of the cell. The capacities of the cells with CNT and CNT-CoN modified separators are inferior at all rates, and the capacities only remain 550 and 670 mAh g−1 at 3 C, respectively. Moreover, as can be derived from the charge–discharge curves in Fig. S10(a–c), the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator exerts the lowest polarization at all rates (Fig. 4b). The polarization voltage of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separators is only 0.30 V at 3 C, which is smaller than those of the cells with CNT (0.61 V) and CNT-CoN (0.44 V) modified separators. The favorable rate performance and polarization voltage of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separators verify that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies can accelerate redox kinetics of LiPSs. The electrochemical properties of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separators exceed most previous studies (Fig. 4c), indicating the superiority of CNT-CoN-VN as a separator modification material [13,40,43–52]. Long-term cycle performance test was further conducted to assess the cycling stability of the cells with CNT-CoN-VN modified separators. As shown in Fig. S11, after 250 cycles at 2 C, the capacity remains 660 mAh g−1 with capacity decay per cycle of only 0.09 % and Coulombic efficiency of close to 100%. As can be observed from the charge–discharge curves (Fig. S12), the total discharge capacity consists of high-voltage plateau capacity (QH) related to the transformation from S8 to Li2S4 and low-voltage plateau capacity (QL) related to the transformation from Li2S4 to Li2S. Apparently, QH and QL of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator are the highest, which indicates that creating nitrogen vacancies in CoN can strongly enhance the redox conversion and the utilization of sulfur species. Besides, the long cycle performance of the cell with the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator at 2 C is compared with the results in other literature (Table S1). It can be clearly seen that the electrochemical properties of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separators exceed most previous studies, indicating the superiority of CNT-CoN-VN as a separator modification material. Considering the practical application of Li-S batteries, the performance of the cells based on CNT-CoN-VN modified separators with higher sulfur loadings is displayed in Fig. 4(d). An impressive capacity of 990 mAh g−1 (4.5 mAh cm−2) after 50 cycles is obtained with coulombic efficiency of nearly 100%. In addition, reducing the dosage of electrolyte is beneficial to further increase the energy density of Li-S batteries. The cycling performance of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator under the condition of E/S = 7 μL mg−1 is shown in Figure S13. The cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator can achieve an impressive capacity of 658 mAh g−1 at 0.8 mA cm−2 after 50 cycles. The comparison between this work and other literatures is shown in Table S2. Under the sulfur loading of 4.5 mg cm−2, the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator exhibits a superior electrochemical performance, confirming that the CNT-CoN-VN can be an outstanding candidate for separator modification material for high-efficient Li-S batteries. In order to further study the kinetics of electrochemical reaction for Li-S batteries, CV tests of the cells with CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators at 0.1 mV s−1 were carried out (Fig. 5 a). The two cathodic peaks are associated with the reduction from S8 to Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) to Li2S, and the anodic peak is associated with the oxidation from Li2S to S8. Obviously, the large peak current and small electrochemical polarization of CNT-CoN-VN both manifest the superiority of CNT-CoN-VN for catalytic conversion of LiPSs. Besides, Tafel slopes are the lowest either for the delithiation (124 mV dec−1) or lithiation (50 mV dec−1) reactions (Fig. S14). Therefore, it can be concluded that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies to CNT-CoN can accelerate the catalytic process of LiPSs conversion. Moreover, the CV tests were also conducted at different scan rates (Fig. S15) to investigate the lithium ion diffusion coefficient (D Li +) according to the Randles-Sevcik equation [53]. The D Li + of the cells with CNT, CNT-CoN and CNT-CoN-VN modified separators were calculated on the basis of the slops of the linear plots (Fig. S16). As summarized in Table S3, the largest D Li + of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator indicates that the presence of nitrogen vacancies in CNT-CoN-VN can effectively accelerate the Li+ transportation during the electrochemical reactions. According to the Nyquist plots (Fig. 5b), the lithium ion conductivity of separators is calculated based on σ = l/(R b × A) [54]., where σ represents the ionic conductivity, l is the thickness of the separator, R b stands for the bulk resistance, and A refers to the area of the stainless steel electrode. The Nyquist plots in the high frequency region for all separators show straight lines, and the intercepts on the x-axis represent the R b. The ionic conductivity of the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator (0.942 mS cm−1) is larger than those of the CNT-CoN modified separator (0.819 mS cm−1) and CNT modified separator (0.771 mS cm−1). Hence, the superb lithium ion conductivity of CNT-CoN-VN modified separator also contributes to the excellent electrochemical performance. The superior kinetics for LiPSs conversion in the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator is also demonstrated by EIS (Fig. 5c and d). In the equivalent circuits, R e represents interphase contact resistance of the electrolyte and cell, R ct represents the charge transfer resistance, and R sf represents the resistance generated from the Li2S/Li2S2 insulating layer. The fitted results are collected in Table S4. Obviously, the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator exhibits the smallest R ct values before and after cycling, verifying that the introduced nitrogen vacancies could promote the charge transfer rate during the redox reactions. Noticeably, the lowest R sf of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator after cycling can be due to the uniform deposition of Li2S2/Li2S. To further prove the ability of the CNT-CoN-VN to alleviate LiPSs shuttle during the discharge/charge process, in-situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted to dynamically monitor the shuttle of LiPSs to the anode side of the separator at different voltages. For the discharge process of the cell with CNT-CoN modified separator (Fig. S17a and b), distinct peaks (S8 2−) at 219 and 478 cm−1 are detected in the beginning, indicating that long-chain S8 2− is easily formed [55]. Meanwhile, the peaks at around 275, 400 and 455 cm−1 appear, which represent the mid-length and short-chain S4 2−, S4 2−/S6 2− and S4 2−/ S3 2−, respectively [56]. As the discharge progresses, the two peaks at 219 and 478 cm−1 gradually disappear, while the peaks of mid-length and short-chain LiPSs are still visible. In the charging process, the characteristic peaks (S8 2−, S6 2−, S4 2− and S3 2−) remain, indicating the serious irreversible shuttle of LiPSs. In contrast, only faint LiPSs signals are observed during both discharge and charge processes of the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator (Fig. S17c and d), which indicates the introduction of nitrogen vacancies effectively inhibits the shuttle of LiPSs to the anode side. The surface morphology of the separators and the lithium anodes after cycling were also investigated to verify the superiority of the CNT-CoN-VN coating layer. As shown in Fig. S18, the surface of modification layers remains integrity after cycling, demonstrating that the modification layer exerts the favorable structure stability during the charge–discharge cycles. In the meantime, as displayed in Fig. S19, the Li metal surface of the cell with the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator is relatively smooth with less corrosion after cycles as compared with the rough Li surfaces of the cells with the CNT and CNT-CoN modified separators. Besides, the corresponding S mapping (inset) shows that the deposited sulfur element on the surface of Li anode cycled with the CNT-CoN-VN modified separator is less than those on the surfaces of Li anodes cycled with the CNT and CNT-CoN modified separators. The above results indicate that the separator modified with CNT-CoN-VN can reduce the occurrence of side reactions caused by the LiPSs shuttle, thus inhibiting the corrosion of Li metal surface during cycles. The CV curves of the symmetric cell using CNT-CoN-VN electrode and Li2S6 electrolyte are measured at 500 mV s−1 to verify the stability of CNT-CoN-VN during cycling (Fig. S20). After 250 cycles, the curves still coincide well, indicating the good electrochemical stability of CoN-VN. Meanwhile, the TEM and HR-TEM have been characterized after 250 cycles. As shown in Fig. S21, the fringe spacing of 0.21 nm is in agreement with the (200) crystal planes of CoN, and no other phases of cobalt-compounds are observed. These results demonstrate the good stability of the CoN-VN in the cycle process. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were adopted to further clarify the interaction mechanism between LiPSs and CNT-CoN-VN. The optimized adsorption configurations and corresponding binding energy results were exhibited in Fig. S22 and Fig. 6(a). The binding energies between CNT-CoN-VN and Li2S6, Li2S4 and Li2S (−0.82, −1.41, and −0.67 eV, respectively) are larger than those of CNT-CoN with Li2S6, Li2S4 and Li2S (−0.54, −0.86, and −0.52 eV, respectively). This result indicates that introducing nitrogen vacancies can enhance the interaction between CNT-CoN-VN and LiPSs. Besides, the positions of the d band center of Co and p band center of N for transition metal nitride also play a major role in improving electrochemical activity [57] Compared with CNT-CoN, the CNT-CoN-VN exerts a reduced band gap between d band center of Co (−1.75 eV vs. −1.04 eV) and p band center of N (−3.29 eV vs −2.14 eV) (Fig. 6b and c). The smaller band gap can expedite the charge transfer and the conversion of LiPSs [58]. Besides, for the two systems of CNT-CoN-Li2S4 and CNT-CoN-VN-Li2S4, the density of states (DOS) of Li2S4 were exhibited in Fig. 6(d and e). Clearly, more electrons of Li2S4 near Fermi level in CNT-CoN-VN-Li2S4 system (25.9) compared with the CNT-CoN-Li2S4 system (11.91) are inclined to participate in the redox reaction of Li2S4 and thus accelerating the conversion of Li2S4. As shown in Fig. 6(f) and Fig. S23, the diffusion energy barriers for LiPSs on the surface of CNT-CoN-VN are lower, indicating that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies into CoN can facilitate the diffusion of LiPSs, and thus is conducive to the improvement of redox reaction kinetics. 4 Conclusions In summary, CNT-CoN with abundant nitrogen vacancies has been designed and used as a model to study the roles of nitrogen vacancies in Li-S batteries. The experimental evidence and theoretical calculation indicate that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies into cobalt nitride can enhance the chemical affinity to LiPSs and effectively hamper the shuttle effect. Meanwhile, the band gap of CNT-CoN-VN is reduced and the diffusion of Li+ is promoted, which contribute to the accelerated redox kinetics in the solid–liquid and liquid–liquid conversions of LiPSs. Through creating nitrogen vacancies, the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator delivers a high initial capacity of 901 mAh g−1 and good cycling stability at 2 C. In addition, an outstanding capacity of 990 mAh g−1 is acquired at the sulfur loading of 4.5 mg cm−2. This work illuminates the enhancement mechanism of nitrogen vacancies in Li-S batteries and gives new insight into the engineering of anion-deficient materials for high efficient Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: While lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery has attracted remarkable attention owing to the high theoretical capacity, its practical application is still hindered by the shuttle and sluggish conversion kinetics of intermediate lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). Defect engineering, which can regulate the electronic structure and in turn influence the surface adsorption and catalytic capability, has been regarded as a feasible strategy to deal with the above challenges. However, few studies on nitrogen vacancies and their mechanisms are reported. Herein, cobalt nitride with nitrogen vacancies grown on multi-walled carbon nanotube (CNT-CoN-VN) is designed and applied as the separator modification material to investigate the enhancing mechanism of nitrogen vacancies on Li-S batteries. The experimental evidence and theoretical calculation indicate that the introduction of nitrogen vacancies into cobalt nitride can enhance the chemical affinity to LiPSs and effectively hamper the shuttle effect. Meanwhile the reduced band gap of the d-band center of Co and p-band center of N for CNT-CoN-VN and the promoted diffusion of Li+ can expedite the solid–liquid and liquid–liquid conversions of sulfur species. Due to these superiorities, the cell with CNT-CoN-VN modified separator delivers a favorable initial capacity of 901 mAh g−1 and a capacity of 660 mAh g−1 can be achieved after 250 cycles at 2 C. This work explores the application of metal nitride with nitrogen vacancies and sheds light on the development of functional separators for high-efficient Li-S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Enhancing anchoring and catalytic conversion of polysulfides by nitrogen deficient cobalt nitride for advanced lithium-sulfur batteries
